repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Koudougou Agricultural Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Report
            (PCR) for the Koudougou Agricultural Pilot Project in
            Burkina Faso for which credit was approved on September 21,
            1982. The credit was closed on March 31, 1989, six months
            behind schedule. It was not fully disbursed and a balance of
            was cancelled. The last disbursement was made on October 27,
            1989. The main objective of the Pilot Project was to
            determine (i) if a number of economically viable technical
            messages existed for the northern part of the CRPA, and if
            their application would produce good results; and (ii) if it
            was possible to overcome the socio-cultural and demographic
            factors hindering the adoption of proven technical
            innovations applicable to the southern part. To accomplish
            this, the project was to identify and put into place an
            agricultural system based on methods capable of preventing,
            slowing or indeed totally stopping soil degradation. The
            system as defined was to have been able to be applied in
            similar agro-ecological regions in the country without major
            modifications. Lessons learned include: the first lesson to
            be learned from this pilot project is that extension staff
            can be made to work far more effectively, provided they are
            well organized and priority is put on diagnosis of problems
            and technical competence in their regular training. The
            staffs in the pilot project were indeed above-average and
            they were closely supervised. Thus,-extrapolation from the
            pilot areas will not be simple but the key elements for
            success are now well known. The second lesson is that there
            are benefits to be derived from doing applied research with
            a network of interested volunteer farmers. First of all like
            most volunteers, the farmers who volunteered to do the
            testing were keenly interested in their work and performed
            the test well. Second these farmers were not only able to
            see for themselves how the proposed technical message worked
            through the duration of the experiment but also how to adapt
            the technical content of the test as experience was gained.

repnme.cdata!: Burkina Faso - Koudougou Agricultural Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:

repnme.cdata!: Upper Volta - Koudougou Agricultural Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Koudougou Pilot Agricultural Project
            will consist of strengthening and reorganizing the extension
            service according to the training and visit system and
            provision of inputs and equipment. Modifications will be
            made and new elements added, to adopt existing extension
            recommendations to the particular soil and climatic
            conditions of the project area. New recommendations will be
            the use of local rock phosphate with or without urea, the
            introduction of drought-resistant crop varieties, crop
            association methods and fallowing practices, the integration
            of animal husbandry and crop cultivation as well as the
            construction of contour bunds by means of animal traction.
            The project will include an adaptive research component,
            which will conduct the necessary trials. Because the project
            stresses the need for integration of animal husbandry and
            crop cultivation, it will also contain an animal health
            component. A strong monitoring and evaluation unit will
            determine to what extent the techniques will be successful
            by conducting a base line survey at the start of the project
            and follow-up of key technical parameters (particularly
            fertilizer response rates). Special emphasis will be placed
            on the study of farm budgets for various farming systems.
